results.title: Bridging the gap: the many worlds of Mandawuy
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Rhoda Roberts (Vox Populi), Sonia Voumard (The Age) and Mandawauy Yunupingu (teacher, musician, ambassador and father).
Mandawuy explores the ways he is bridging the gap between black and white culture through both his band Yothu Yindi, and as the Principal of the Yirrkala Community School in North East Arnhem Land, where, he devised the curriculum mix of First Nations peoples’ and western studies known as “Both Ways Education”.

results.title: The Dalai Lama of Tibet
results.creator_credit: Austin Steele, John Walsh and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
The Dalai Lama answers questions at a press conference in Perth as part of his Australian tour. He discusses his philosophy of compassion in relation to conflict and political struggle, with particular reference to the Chinese invasion of Tibet. He also provides a brief outline of the events arising from the Chinese invasion. The Dalai Lama is the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people and an inspiration to thousands around the world. He has been living in exile since 1959.

results.title: Australia 2001:Thomas Keneally leads the push for a republi
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Thomas Keneally (Chairman of the Australian Republican Movement), David McNichol (The Bulletin) and D.D. McNichol (The Australian) on the issue of a Repblican Australia by the year 2001. They discuss the potential benefits to Australia becoming a republic, when this is likely to cccur, the politicalisation and composition of the Republican movement, possible candidates for Head of State and selection criteria, the Constitutional Commission 1988 and the liklihood of a hidden agenda within the Republican movement to undermine the current political system.

results.title: Sir David Attenborough
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Sir David Attenborough talks with three Australian journalists about his life’s work, what influences him, how he feels about his work, his thoughts on society and the environment, and his optimistic view of the future.

results.title: Three Prime Ministers
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Three of the most significant politicians in recent Australian history are interviewed on their visions for Australia in the 21st Century. Gough Whitlam, Malcolm Fraser and Bob Hawke discuss what they see as the most important issues confronting Australia in the 1990’s, including the question of reconciliation between white and black Australians; the importance of trade and cultural links with Asia; the increasingly debilitating effects of permanent unemployment; and the possible consequences of republicanism on Australian identity and notions of statehood. The interviewers on this episode of “Face the Press” are Phillip Adams, Amanda Buckley and Paul Murphy.

results.title: Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: An outstanding documentary series examining the history of rock and roll which contains in-depth interviews with pivotal figures in rock and roll history and rare footage of performances by legendary artists. The research and in-depth analysis make this worth watching.

results.title: Make it funky. Planet rock.
results.creator_credit: Don Letts, Yvonne Smith, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Afro-american musicians developed their own unique style which celebrated their rich cultural heritage. The episode ‘Make it funky’ features interviews and perfomances by such legends as James Brown, Sly and the Family Stone, Stevie Wonder and Marvin Gaye. The final episode in the series ‘Planet rock’ looks at rap, hip-hop and techno and the use of computers as musical instruments which allow music to become an instant global experience. Features interviews and clips from New Order, The Beastie Boys and Public Enemy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Letts, Yvonne Smith, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: Hang onto yourself: no fun
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
In ‘Hang onto yourself’, this episode features an in-depth look at the many faces of David Bowie, particularly as the glam phenomena Ziggy Stardust. The rise of performers such as Alice Cooper, Lou Reed and Ziggy is seen as a response to the hangover from the summer of love where rock developed theatricality. The rise of Reggae and Punk music is the subject of the episode entitled ‘No fun’ and features clips and interviews with pivotal figures such as Malcolm McClaren, The Sex Pistols, Bob Marley and Talking Heads.

results.title: Crossroads. Eight miles high
results.creator_credit: Alan Lewens, Karen Walsh, Mick Conefrey, High Thomson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
The Blues crosses the Atlantic and reaches Britain where it finds a new direction. Groups like the Beatles and the Rolling Stones invade America and somewhere in the process Heavy Metal is invented. In this episode entitled ‘Crossroads’, interviews and performances by legendary musicians such as The Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck are featured. In the second program ‘Eight miles high’ the whole phenomenon of Psychadelia is explored, including interviews and clips from The Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin and Pink Floyd. This episode captures a landmark era in the development of rock music in the 1960’s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Lewens, Karen Walsh, Mick Conefrey, High Thomson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: Whole lotta shaking: R.E.S.P.E.C.T.
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Whole lotta shakin examines the grass roots beginnings of rock and roll. In New Orleans, Afro-american performers like Little Richard were unleashing a new type of music which echoed through the Mississippi Delta into Sam Phillips’ Studio in Memphis. What was predominantly Afro-american music became “legitimised” commercially when singers like Elvis Presley emulated this energetic form of music. “R.E.S.P.E.C.T”: Motown and Stax records paved the way for legendary Afro-american singers to become successful in their own right. Aretha Franklin was the Queen of Soul, but artists like Ray Charles, Martha Reeves, Otis Redding and the Supremes also made their mark as rock and roll legends.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
